question.text: During transcription the template strand is the one with polarity

options.text: Always 3' to 5' as the template strand
Always 5' to 3' as the template strand
Any of the strands can become template strand.
Alternatively both strand work as template strand.

solution.text:
Transcription occurs in only one direction. Thus the strand that has the polarity 3'→5' acts as the template strand. The other strand which has the polarity 5'→3' is referred to as the coding strand.

Transcription whether prokaryotic or eukaryotic has three main events.

•   Initiation - Binding of RNA polymerase to double-stranded DNA; this step involves a transition to single strandedness in the region of binding; RNA polymerase binds at 5’ end on a sequence of DNA called the promoter. Initiation is the most important step in gene expression.

•   Elongation - The covalent addition of nucleotides to the 3' end of the growing polynucleotide chain. This involves the development of a short stretch of DNA that is transiently single-stranded.

•   Termination - The recognition of the transcription termination sequence and the release of RNA polymerase. The promoter and terminator flank the structural gene in a transcription unit.
